CARPE DIEM VISUAL NOVEL FAST REVIEW (NO SPOILERS)

I liked it. Not heaps, but it was ok.


-The story only went for around 7min's (i'm not the fastest reader, but i wouldn't say i'm a slow reader either, so i'm maybe average??), but i was entertained for those 7min's, & thats what matters. It even surprised me at the end, which is always a bonus.

I think there were 4-5 different backgrounds, with each background showing the same character, who's only variety was when she'd open & close her mouth during dialogue, as well as the occasional blink. Oh, sorry, i forgot, her cheeks also get red at times.
-The music was fine. Mellow piano playing, but for only 7min's, so i didn't get sick of it.

So, the game altogether was ok. Nothing blow-away spectacular, but all in all, a good experience. Maybe if it was longer, i wouldn't have liked it as much.

Also, i haven't mentioned, this VN was the maker's first effort & it's free, so i think you've got to allow for that as well. I'd rather make an average first game than a crappy one, & this isn't crappy (just average).

5/10

Carper Diem were to start, well Id like to  preface this by saying that like with all of my reviews I waited till I had spent a great deal of time with the subject matter.

The story is a bittersweet journey in the shoes of the main character, Jung, where you will spend your time going out on a date with a girl named Ai. You have a day to enjoy your date and see the world from Jung's point-of-view.

Length wise it is not the longest VN I have come across, Id hazard a guess to say it is in fact one of the shortest Ive read, but it doesn't need to be any longer, it tells its story well in the period of time needed, some maybe disappointed at its short length but overall I didn't have a problem with it, although yes it would have been nice if it had gone longer.

The art style is some what basic but this can be forgiven all things considered, though I will say Carper Diem has a certain charm to it.

The music while like the art is pretty basic, however I will say it does try to add to the atmosphere and does its job as best it can to complement the game.

Overall Carper Diem is a well written piece of work; Visually its alright, music its average however its the ending that is what really sold it for me.

I'll leave you with this, Carper Diem is a good read and will no doubt keep you interested throughout its duration, and its absolutely free if that's not a good reason to check it out I don't know what is....so why not give it a try.

reviewText:
What am I doing with my life?

Reading this Visual Novel is one of the reasons why I liked VNs in general. It all depends on the creator whether his work will flourish or stay where it is.

Carpe Diem is a free short Visual Novel that tells the story of a man meeting up with his girlfriend (but is that really?). I don't want to further spoil the story, as it is only a short VN, and you will get there eventually.

I am absolutely amazed at how a simple VN turns out to be so fulfilling.

Carpe Diem tackles about reality, and how you incorporate illusion from reality itself.

And most of all,it tackled one of the most controversial aspects of an AI, which is the Turing's Test.


Pros:
- Nicely-drawn character and background
- Simple background music that is pleasing to the ear
- A direct-to-the-point story plot
- Light humor that incorporates to the conversation between the MC and the other character

Cons:
- Very short VN (It is, indeed)
- The choices seemed unecessary for me, as they do not really divert from each other.
- Some CG with the MC and the MC would be nice, especially in some events.



Carpe Diem may be the first VN of the creator, but I can confidently say that he can go a long way if he continues making VNs. I bought the Extra Package DLC to support this author. So if you liked this VN, please buy it too!



Overall I'd totally recommend this to those who likes VNs. It may also teach you how to start making VNs for yourself, too.

reviewText:
As many people have pointed out, this game is short. It took me 20 minutes to run through six routes (each of the three routes, twice). It's short, simple, and to the point. If you're looking for a vast plot, a deeply branching storyline, this is not it. But Carpe Diem proves that a good visual novel--a good game--doesn't need to be superfluous or complicated to be good. It's an experience that's relatable, personal, it'll make you feel something inside. I'm sure that most people who are reviewing this game positively, myself included, are doing so for this experience. The story is a real piece of art (if you disagree, you try writing something so short and effective, it's not easy), and the overall integration of all the elements (writing, art, music, pacing) makes this a masterpiece in the VN genre.

For the cost of 20 minutes, it's certainly worth experiencing. I'd recommend it to anyone.

Oh, and the title (or rather the title screen) will make more sense to you after you've beaten the game once.

reviewText:
So I picked this up having seen many positive recommendations for it in steam, as well as mentioning that the game is pretty short.

The author mentions this is a first effort, and for a first effort its solid. Its got consistent (but rather bland) art with not many expressions and basic transitions.

The music is appaling, two or three very short loops of crappy synthesised pianos which drill in my head. I had to turn the music off.

The writing is what makes a visual novel, and sadly the writing is average. Its not bad, but it does not excel in any way. The visual novel trope of having the main character monolouge things to himself that would be known knowledge to them is present here for some reason which begs the question why words were wasted on it, considering the story is very short and is trying to be very on point with its message. The story gets the message over, and has an interesting idea, but sadly it does not really do anything with it.

As I said, this is a good first time effort and as practice for developing VN's its a good start, but as a consumer I don't see a reason to recommend this to anyone as the story does not even ask any questions or engage the player in any way.

Carpe Diem, despite having only one ending, gives the player some choices (albeit not a lot) in the game that create some branches in the story.
However, each of choices that the player is given sort of intertwine with each other.
When replaying the game and picking a different option, you'll notice that certain dialogues are reused in the branch.
The story itself isn't very long. It probably wouldn't take you more than an hour to try all the different options in the game.

I find the assets in the game to be somewhat bland. The musics in the game aren't very interesting to listen to and I actually even muted the background music after a bit of playing and decided to just fire up Steam Music Player to listen to my own collection of songs as I play the game.
The scenery backgrounds look kinda odd to me. They don't seem to match the art style that was used to draw the main female Character, Ai. I think they could use some polishing.

Another shortcoming that I found in the game is the UI. While the UI of the menu doesn't look that bad, the UI for the controls are hardly visible.
When I first started the game, I was very confused that I couldn't find the UI for standard controls to Save, Quick Save, Skip, etc.
I thought I was supposed to somehow know all the possible shortcuts on my own, but as it turns out, the game does have UI implemented, but it's virtually invisible.
It was so difficult to spot, that I actually found it by accident when I pressed random buttons on my controller and accidentally selected one of the control button displayed in the
bottom right corner of the screen.

Overall, it's not a particularly bad game, but it can definitely use some improvements.
I think the most important thing to address is the disappointingly short story.
Additionally, aside from all the other issues that I've mentioned above, I'd like to see some other improvements, perhaps some animation for the transition? Or some improvements for Ai's character?
I mean, I'd say she's pretty likable, but I also find her to be somewhat unpredictable based on her reactions to certain situations :P

I have some very mixed feelings about the game and it's a bit difficult for me to decide whether this is a game that I'd recommend to people who enjoy visual novels in general.
However, despite all the shortcomings that I've mentioned above, the game did leave some impression on me, mainly because of the twist at the end.
Even though, it was somewhat spoiled because I saw the achievement (that has now been renamed to something else) before I played the game, the twist was still a bit unexpected as one wouldn't be able to tell the details from just the achievement's name.

If you're someone who enjoys visual novels and wanting to play some, go ahead and give this one a shot. It's short, but hey it's also free :D

reviewText:
Carpe Diem is pretty much exactly as it describes itself. It's a short VN with one non-critical decision and a pretty ok story and conclusion for its length. It won't take you more than 10 or so minutes to give it a look, and considering it's free and you're probably reading this on its store page, why not?

Pros:
+Art is pretty good, even if there's not much to see.
+Delivers a message you might pay $5+ to see from some other indie game, for free and with less pretension in less time!
+Has a pretty fully fleshed out options menu for a 10 minute game. All your VN basics are there including saves and dialog skipping, skip only seen etc.
+Multiple language support.
+You can buy an extras pack DLC if you want to support the developer. It doesn't contain content locked out from the main game so you won't miss out on anything either.
?Easy perfect game for your steam achievements collection.

Neutral points:
=I guessed the twist before I started the game.
=The only choice in the game isn't too important since each route can lead to at least one of the other locations you can pick from eventually. You will miss a few scenes if you don't try them all though.
=The music isn't great but I also didn't find it annoying.
=No voice acting but I'd hardly expect that from a free game and let alone a dev's first VN.

Cons:
-There's quite a few grammatical errors, at least in English. I cannot speak for the other languages available. UPDATE: Eyzi has corrected the mistakes I spotted.
-The writing is a little stiff. Would have benefited from some creative writing techniques. It's not all bad though, both Jung and Ai have some character to them. Some.

reviewText:
Carpe Diem is pretty much exactly as it describes itself. It's a short VN with one non-critical decision and a pretty ok story and conclusion for its length. It won't take you more than 10 or so minutes to give it a look, and considering it's free and you're probably reading this on its store page, why not?

Pros:
+Art is pretty good, even if there's not much to see.
+Delivers a message you might pay $5+ to see from some other indie game, for free and with less pretension in less time!
+Has a pretty fully fleshed out options menu for a 10 minute game. All your VN basics are there including saves and dialog skipping, skip only seen etc.
+Multiple language support.
+You can buy an extras pack DLC if you want to support the developer. It doesn't contain content locked out from the main game so you won't miss out on anything either.
?Easy perfect game for your steam achievements collection.

Neutral points:
=I guessed the twist before I started the game.
=The only choice in the game isn't too important since each route can lead to at least one of the other locations you can pick from eventually. You will miss a few scenes if you don't try them all though.
=The music isn't great but I also didn't find it annoying.
=No voice acting but I'd hardly expect that from a free game and let alone a dev's first VN.

Cons:
-There's quite a few grammatical errors, at least in English. I cannot speak for the other languages available. UPDATE: Eyzi has corrected the mistakes I spotted.
-The writing is a little stiff. Would have benefited from some creative writing techniques. It's not all bad though, both Jung and Ai have some character to them. Some.

reviewText:
Spoiler-free review:If you are a fan of visual novels, try it right now, trust me. You will really enjoy it. It's short, it's free; you don't have any excuses. I can't tell you any reasons because it would spoil the whole game, so you will have to trust me here: you should deffinetively give it a chance.


Spoiler-loaded review:Despite looking like a simple idea at first glance, the point is that it works. There could be 50000 visual novels that talk about seizing the day through the experiences of their characters, but only in this one the line that differences between the character and you is so thin that is dfficult to draw. This is not an inspiring pre-recorded message, it's a slap of reality aired live.

The problem is that the target audience of this game, the people who can synergize with it, is very narrow. The only people who will really catch the message are those fans of the visual novels, anime and manga that take their hobby a step further in a bad way.

And yes, we could talk about that all this could have been executed in a better way; in the end what we've been reviewing until now its the idea per se, not the product offered here. The point is that it could seem that a better execution could have permitted that this game, this message, arrived to a wider audience, but I don't think so. The message this game wants to send us is very simple. You don't have to adorn it more because the public it aims for is rarely talked about this theme. A one on one conversation about this conflictive topic, from a position that usually inspires safety and comfort: it's the only thing you need to get this message through.

In conclusion, this is a niche piece, executed in a simplistic way (but let's no forget that this is the author's first work, Eyzi, who happens to be an indie developer that works by him/herself), but very interesting and that will surely work with a lot of people. Deffinetively very worth of checking out.


!Disclaimer! This is my first visual novel and my first steam review, so I might be full of sh‚ô•t. But my intention is that this review does justice to the game, the public and the author, so I will gladly appreciate any critique to it; thanks for reading.

reviewText: I was hesistant to pick this game up after reading all the reviews. While it is free It is extremely short. However, that is probably it's greatest strength. It's charming and lasts just long enough to be interested in the characters and not bore. Even with the story on the slowest Auto setting I managed to take all three routes within an hour while taking a snack break between each turn. That's right there are only 3 routes, each of which ends the same way. Each playthrough will follow the same general path. The twist at the end tho changed the way I thought about the story during my second and thrid play through.\n\nThe story and music were delightful. The only real complaint I have is that there isn't enough art. There are a total of 6 backrounds and you will spend most of that time looking at a slightly changing Ai. There are a few interesting parts to the story that I would have loved to see. For such a short story with such limited content this was a true missed opportunity. All in all I really enjoyed this first attempt and I look forward to how Eyzi, the developer, grows from here.

reviewText:
Spoiler-free review:If you are a fan of visual novels, try it right now, trust me. You will really enjoy it. It's short, it's free; you don't have any excuses. I can't tell you any reasons because it would spoil the whole game, so you will have to trust me here: you should deffinetively give it a chance.


Spoiler-loaded review:Despite looking like a simple idea at first glance, the point is that it works. There could be 50000 visual novels that talk about seizing the day through the experiences of their characters, but only in this one the line that differences between the character and you is so thin that is dfficult to draw. This is not an inspiring pre-recorded message, it's a slap of reality aired live.

The problem is that the target audience of this game, the people who can synergize with it, is very narrow. The only people who will really catch the message are those fans of the visual novels, anime and manga that take their hobby a step further in a bad way.

And yes, we could talk about that all this could have been executed in a better way; in the end what we've been reviewing until now its the idea per se, not the product offered here. The point is that it could seem that a better execution could have permitted that this game, this message, arrived to a wider audience, but I don't think so. The message this game wants to send us is very simple. You don't have to adorn it more because the public it aims for is rarely talked about this theme. A one on one conversation about this conflictive topic, from a position that usually inspires safety and comfort: it's the only thing you need to get this message through.

In conclusion, this is a niche piece, executed in a simplistic way (but let's no forget that this is the author's first work, Eyzi, who happens to be an indie developer that works by him/herself), but very interesting and that will surely work with a lot of people. Deffinetively very worth of checking out.


!Disclaimer! This is my first visual novel and my first steam review, so I might be full of sh‚ô•t. But my intention is that this review does justice to the game, the public and the author, so I will gladly appreciate any critique to it; thanks for reading.

reviewText:
Hi all,

I liked:
It was hilarious to me that the protagonist Jung, did not have a great deal in common with their programmed Ai girl friend, there was friction, sarcasm and antagonism. Which reminds me of the simple truth that opposites attract and yet such differences also cause friction.

Disliked:
I simply didn't understand why Jung would question, what he was doing with his life after his Ai girl friend crashed. I had noted that Jung appeared to enjoy her company, despite the considerable limitations of their relationship. Why should his relationship as it was, with some manner of synthetic (software) individual be judged as anyway inferior to any other relationship, real or imagined, synthetic or otherwise?
It is evident that many people live their lives in a very lonely fashion, yet PC (Personal Computer) uptake appears to be considerable. Therefore the thought experiment that the game explores, namely human beings developing relationships with Ai software has considerable merit. Many lonely people with access to PCs and such software could develop relationship within the technological constraints of such. I argue then that numerous people's lives could be bettered by the ubiquitous use of such Ai. I suggest that far be it from questioning his own life, Jung, could improve his Ai and eventually with persistence, make a lot of lonely people happier. Maybe even himself.
The implied notion that there is a perfect (or even any) partner just waiting for each of us to approach in real life, is naive and I argue, the greatest fantasy associated with this game.

Good gaming,
Alter

I suggest that we all enjoy our fantasies, they may be all we have, they may be all we will ever have. I recommend against denouncing them as somehow inferior or unworthy and suggest instead embracing them as part of who we are.
